descriptionProfile: Tropical biologist turned photojournalist for National Geographic Magazine. Please read our NatGeo online article: How to Photograph an Orchid
Tropical biologist turned photojournalist for National Geographic Magazine. Please read our NatGeo online article: How to Photograph an Orchid

posts.description: Photo by @christianziegler  Courting bees and beetles, the nectar less pansy orchid impersonates a nutrition-rich neighbor, the pea flower. This is part of an article on NG online about how to photograph orchids. This is part of an article on NG online about how to photograph orchids. Please check it out: How to Photograph an Orchid, see link in bio.

Photo by @christianziegler  A field portrait of a hammer orchid (Drakaea sp.). This must be the weirdest looking orchid I photographed - the flower didn’t even look like a flower. It is pollinated by male wasps that it deceives by imitating a female wasp in both looks and scent. This is part of an article on NG online about how to photograph orchids. Please check it out: How to Photograph an Orchid, see link in bio.

Photo by @christianziegler. Parasitic wasps pollinate this funky, striped orchid that is native to southwestern Australia. Swarms of little wasps are attracted to this crab spider orchid by its scent. This is part of an article on NG online about how to photograph orchids. Please check it out: How to Photograph an Orchid, see link in bio. #orchids #wasps #Australia @natgeo

Merry Christmas….. meet the kinkajou (Potos flavus), the king of the tree crown in Central America. At night, kinkajous are the dominant animals in the Balsa tree (Ochroma pyramidale) and chase everybody out of the canopy so they can have the nectar to themselves - each flower can hold up to 50 ml of sugary nectar. Kinkajous are very important pollinators and seed dispersers of many species of rain forest trees, and they are the primary pollinator of the Ochroma tree pictured here. The kinkajous visit to drink nectar from the huge flowers and while drinking their furry cheeks get dusted in pollen that they carry to the next flower. This picture was taken from atop of a 100 ft tower to access the forest canopy in central Panama. @thephotosociety @natgeocreative #Panama #conservation

Photo by @christianziegler. I recently got interviewed by Canon Professional Network about my work and philosophy. Please follow the link in my bio, if you are interested. 
I found this beautiful skull lying on a beach on Jicaron Island (a small island to the south of Coiba), its probably from a little whale or a dolphin. Coiba is Central America’s largest uninhabited island (some 500 square kilometers) and sits just off the Pacific coast of Panama. It is a truly unique place with many endemic species of animals and plants. It was a penal colony for almost 100 years until 10 years ago, and so it is still covered with lush rainforest that has long gone on the mainland - a time capsule with high conservation value. Together with my colleague @timlaman (under water), @peter_houlihan and @pelletk (video). We are working on a celebrational photo essay about Coiba National Park.

Our expeditions (three so far) are supported by the International League of Conservation Photographers (@ilcp_photographers), el Ministerio de Ambiente Panama @miambientepma and STRI (stri.si.edu). Fusing scientific exploration and photography to support Coiba’s #conservation. GEO magazine published 2 articles about Coiba’s fantastic ecosystem in July and August 2016. #nanpapix #Coiba

Photo by @christianziegler. I recently got interviewed by Canon Professional Network about my work and philosophy. Please follow the link in my bio, if you are interested. 
This enormous crocodile is named ‘Tito’ (almost 4 m or 12 ft); he is well known on Coiba where he usually hangs around in the bay next to the field station.

A male magnificent hummingbird pollinates an Ellianthus orchid in the highlands of western Panama.

Photo by @christianziegler. Studio portrait of a flower of Gustavia superba, a member of the Lecythidaceae  family, and a common species on Jicaron, a small unexplored island in the south of Coiba National Park. Coiba island is Central America’s largest uninhabited island (some 500 square kilometers) and sits just off the Pacific coast of Panama. It is a truly unique place with many endemic species of animals and plants. It was a penal colony for almost 100 years until 10 years ago, and so it is still covered with lush rainforest that has long gone on the mainland - a time capsule with high conservation value. Our expeditions (three so far) are supported by the International League of Conservation Photographers (@ilcp_photographers), el Ministerio de Ambiente Panama @miambientepma and STRI (stri.si.edu). Fusing scientific exploration and photography to support Coiba’s #conservation. GEO magazine published 2 articles about Coiba’s fantastic ecosystem in July and August 2016.

Photo by @christianziegler. Two white-faced capuchin monkeys in threat display on Jicaron, a small island south of Coiba. We encountered them during a hike along the western coast… I think they were very surprised by our presence, who knows when they last saw humans here! Coiba island is Central America’s largest uninhabited island (some 500 square kilometers) and sits just off the Pacific coast of Panama. It is a truly unique place with many endemic species of animals and plants. It was a penal colony for almost 100 years until 10 years ago, and so it is still covered with lush rainforest that has long gone on the mainland - a time capsule with high conservation value. Photo by @christianziegler. A young fig tree overgrows an abandoned jail on Playa Hermoso, Coiba island, Panama. It was hard to locate the ‘building’ or whatever remains of it. In just 12 years, the jungle is rapidly overtaking the jail buildings…in another 10 year it will be gone without trace. Nature rules here now.

Photo by @christianziegler. An epiphytic orchid flowering on Coibita, a small island in Coiba National Park. Photo by @christianziegler Coiba island – the largest uninhabited island off the Pacific coast of the Americas. Coiba National Park is a beautiful reminder of what tropical ecosystems can be; an island covered in pristine forest sitting in a rich ocean just off the coast of Panama. I am super excited to be heading back to Coiba today for two-weeks with @peter_houlihan and @pelletk to continue to document the biodiversity of this unique island ecosystem. This is the first time that I will be back in the field after a year recovering from suffering a stroke in July 2015.... It’s been a tough journey but I’m almost there and it’s wonderful to be getting back to the forest to do what I enjoy most! I won't post for 2 weeks, (no wifi), but after:) Thanks to International League of Conservation Photographers @ilcp_photographers, el Ministerio de Ambiente Panama @miambientepma, and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute for all their support. #Coiba #Biodiversity #Panama #UNESCO #Conservation #Gratitude

Photograph taken by @christianziegler in DRC on assignment for @natgeo, an outtake from a story on Bonobos in March 2013. Here I just captured a quick glance of two bonobos foraging, then after a few seconds they were gone… disappeared into the green of the forest.@thephotosociety @natgeo @natgeocreative #Wpph14 #conservation #ecology #DRC #congo #bonobo

Photograph taken by @christianziegler in DRC on assignment for @natgeo, an outtake from a story on Bonobos in March 2013. Portrait of an older male Bonobo, probably around 35-years old. It is incredibly difficult to see and photograph bonobos in the wild; we tracked them for weeks before I could get close enough to take a portrait.  I enjoyed photographing this male very much, he was so relaxed just sitting in a tree – he seemed to be thinking about something. @thephotosociety @natgeo @natgeocreative #Wpph14 #conservation #ecology #DRC #congo #bonobo

Photograph taken by @christianziegler in DRC on assignment for @natgeo, an outtake from a story on Bonobos in March 2013. After tracking the Bonobos for many weeks they became accustomed to me and sometimes the group would just hangout together - relaxing, stretching and grooming.  This bonobo was lying on its back stretching out his arms. @thephotosociety @natgeo @natgeocreative #Wpph14 #conservation #ecology #DRC #congo #bonobo

Photograph taken by @christianziegler in DRC on assignment for @natgeo, from a story on Bonobos in March 2013. This is a very young Bonobo, maybe less than 3 months old, with her mother. I felt extremely blessed to witness this peaceful scene of a mother holding her sleeping child. @thephotosociety @natgeo @natgeocreative #Wpph14 #conservation #ecology #DRC #congo #bonobo
